name: valley
content:
valley

noun
 
 
/ˈvæli/
 
/ˈvæli/
jump to other results
  1. enlarge image
     an area of low land between hills or mountains, often with a river flowing through it; the land that a river flows through
    • in a valley In the valley below cows were grazing peacefully.
    • the fertile soils of river valleys
    • A stream runs the length of the valley floor.
    • the Shenandoah Valley
    • the valley of the Nile
    • a small town set in a valley
    • The cottage was in a wooded valley.
    • The road climbs up the side of the valley.
    Wordfinder
    • altitude
    • foothill
    • mountain
    • peak
    • precipice
    • ridge
    • slope
    • summit
    • valley
    • volcano
    see also hanging valley, lily of the valley, rift valley
    Extra Examples
    • A large cloud filled the valley and obscured vision.
    • The castle is situated on a hill overlooking a valley.
    • The rivers Rhône and Rhine rise here and form broad valleys.
    • a high hill that dominates the mineral-rich valleys of this region
    • a valley surrounded by mountains
    Topics Geographya2
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadjective
    • broad
    • deep
    • high
    • …
    verb + valley
    • enter
    • leave
    • reach
    • …
    valley + noun
    • bottom
    • floor
    • side
    • …
    preposition
    • in a/​the valley
    See full entry
    Word OriginMiddle English: from Old French valee, based on Latin vallis, valles; compare with vale.

name: Napa Valley
content:
Napa Valley

 
/ˌnæpə ˈvæli/
 
/ˌnæpə ˈvæli/
jump to other results
  1. a valley in the US state of California which is the centre of the US wine industry. It is north of Oakland, and its largest town is Napa.
Check pronunciation: Napa Valley

name: rift valley
content:
rift valley

noun
 
/ˈrɪft væli/
 
/ˈrɪft væli/
jump to other results
  1. a valley with steep sides formed when two tectonic plates move apart from each otherTopics Geographyc2

name: Valley Girl
content:
Valley Girl

noun
 
/ˈvæli ɡɜːl/
 
/ˈvæli ɡɜːrl/
(North American English, informal)
jump to other results
  1. a rich girl who is thought to be only interested in things like fashion, shopping, and physical appearance, considered to be typical of young people living in the San Fernando Valley of California
    Oxford Collocations DictionaryValley Girl is used before these nouns:
    • accent
    See full entry
See Valley Girl in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: Valley Girl

name: Death Valley
content:
Death Valley

 
/ˌdeθ ˈvæli/
 
/ˌdeθ ˈvæli/
jump to other results
  1. a desert covering part of the US states of California and Nevada. It is the lowest land in the western hemisphere, being 282 feet/86 metres below sea level, with very high temperatures (up to 50° Celsius). The desert was a source of the mineral borax in the late 19th century. In 1933, the area became the Death Valley National monument.
Check pronunciation: Death Valley

name: Valley Forge
content:
Valley Forge

 
/ˌvæli ˈfɔːdʒ/
 
/ˌvæli ˈfɔːrdʒ/
jump to other results
  1. an area in the US state of Pennsylvania where General George Washington and his Continental Army spent the severe winter of 1777-8 during the American Revolution. Hundreds died of cold and lack of food, but the army remained loyal.
Check pronunciation: Valley Forge

name: hanging valley
content:
hanging valley

noun
 
/ˌhæŋɪŋ ˈvæli/
 
/ˌhæŋɪŋ ˈvæli/
 (specialist)
jump to other results
  1. a valley that joins a deeper valley, often with a waterfall where the two valleys joinTopics Geographyc2
See hanging valley in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary

name: Monument Valley
content:
Monument Valley

 
/ˌmɒnjumənt ˈvæli/
 
/ˌmɑːnjumənt ˈvæli/
jump to other results
  1. an area in north-eastern Arizona and southern Utah, west of the Four Corners, where many films have been made because of the spectacular scenery
Check pronunciation: Monument Valley

name: Silicon Valley
content:
Silicon Valley

noun
 
/ˌsɪlɪkən ˈvæli/
 
/ˌsɪlɪkən ˈvæli/
[uncountable]
jump to other results
  1. the area in California where there are many companies connected with the computer and electronics industries, sometimes used to refer to any area where there are a lot of computer companies

name: Red River Valley
content:
Red River Valley

 
/ˌred ˌrɪvə ˈvæli/
 
/ˌred ˌrɪvər ˈvæli/
jump to other results
  1. a traditional US song, sung especially by cowboys. It is about a man who is told that the woman he loves is going to move away. It begins with the line 'From this valley they say you are going' and ends: “Come and sit by my side, if you love me.Do not hasten to bid me adieu.Just remember the Red River ValleyAnd the cowboy who loved you so true.”
Check pronunciation: Red River Valley

name: San Joaquin Valley
content:
San Joaquin Valley

 
/ˌsæn wɑːˌkiːn ˈvæli/
 
/ˌsæn wɑːˌkiːn ˈvæli/
jump to other results
  1. a central valley in the US state of California, around the San Joaquin River. It is considered to be one of the best agricultural regions in the US. Farmers there produce such crops as cotton, wheat, nuts, grapes and vegetables.
Check pronunciation: San Joaquin Valley

name: Down in the Valley
content:
Down in the Valley

 
/ˌdaʊn ɪn ðə ˈvæli/
 
/ˌdaʊn ɪn ðə ˈvæli/
jump to other results
  1. a US folk song about a man who asks a woman if she loves him. Kurt Weill wrote an opera (1948) with the same name, based on the song. It begins: “Down in the valley, the valley so low,Hang your head over, hear the winds blow.Hear the winds blow, Dear, hear the winds blow.Hang your head over, hear the winds blow.”
Check pronunciation: Down in the Valley

name: lily of the valley
content:
lily of the valley

noun
 
/ˌlɪli əv ðə ˈvæli/
 
/ˌlɪli əv ðə ˈvæli/
[countable, uncountable]
(plural lilies of the valley)
jump to other results
  1. a plant with small white flowers that are like bells in shape
See lily of the valley in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: lily of the valley

name: the Rhondda Valley
content:
the Rhondda Valley

 
/ðə ˌrɒndə ˈvæli/
 
/ðə ˌrɑːndə ˈvæli/
(also the Rhondda)
jump to other results
  1. an area in south Wales famous for its coal- mining industry in the 19th and early 20th centuries. The last mine closed in 1990.
Check pronunciation: the Rhondda Valley

name: the Shenandoah Valley
content:
the Shenandoah Valley

 
/ðə ˌʃenəndəʊə ˈvæli/
 
/ðə ˌʃenəndəʊə ˈvæli/
jump to other results
  1. a large, beautiful valley in the northern part of the US state of Virginia, between the Allegheny Mountains and the Blue Ridge Mountains. It was used by many Americans when they moved west, and several Civil War battles were fought there because it supplied food for the Confederate forces. The Shenandoah River flows through it and is the subject of the folk song Shenandoah, which begins: ‘Oh Shenandoah, I long to hear you, Away, you rolling river.’ The Shenandoah National Park was established in 1926.
Check pronunciation: the Shenandoah Valley

name: Tennessee Valley Authority
content:
Tennessee Valley Authority

 
/ˌtenəsiː ˈvæli ɔːθɒrəti/
 
/ˌtenəsiː ˈvæli əθɔːrəti/
(abbreviation TVA)
jump to other results
  1. an independent US government organization that provides electricity to seven southern states. TVA was established in 1933 by President Franklin D Roosevelt, as part of his New Deal, to encourage the economic development of the area around the Tennessee River. As well as providing electricity it builds and operates dams (= barriers across rivers), controls floods and protects the soil.
Check pronunciation: Tennessee Valley Authority
